<IMG SRC="g41104g26n00.jpg" ALT="LOGO">
 </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:200pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:33pt; font-family:ARIAL" ALIGN="center"><FONT COLOR="#821928">ILLINOIS TOOL WORKS INC. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="font-size:20pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="line-height:1.0pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:2pt;border-bottom:1px solid #478ef7">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:22pt; font-family:ARIAL" ALIGN="center"><FONT COLOR="#821928">Notice of 2016 Annual Meeting and Proxy Statement </FONT></P>

<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt" ALIGN="center">


<IMG SRC="g41104g26n00.jpg" ALT="LOGO">
 </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:18pt; font-family:ARIAL" ALIGN="center"><B>Illinois Tool Works Inc. </B></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:7pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:16pt; font-family:ARIAL" ALIGN="center"><B>Notice of Annual Meeting of Stockholders </B></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:7pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:12pt; font-family:ARIAL" ALIGN="center"><B>Friday, May&nbsp;6, 2016 </B></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:12pt; font-family:ARIAL" ALIGN="center"><B>9:00 A.M. Central
Daylight Time </B></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:7pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:12pt; font-family:ARIAL" ALIGN="center"><B>Illinois Tool Works Inc. </B></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:12pt; font-family:ARIAL" ALIGN="center"><B>155 Harlem Avenue* </B></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:12pt; font-family:ARIAL" ALIGN="center"><B>Glenview, Illinois 60025
</B></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:7pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">If you plan to attend the meeting, you must be a holder of Illinois Tool Works Inc. shares as of the record date of March&nbsp;8, 2016, and obtain a
registration confirmation (&#147;Ticket&#148;) in advance. Tickets can be printed by accessing Shareholder Meeting Registration at <I><U>www.proxyvote.com</U> </I>and following the instructions provided. You will need the 12-digit number that is
printed in the box marked by the arrow <FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman"><FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:WINGDINGS">&#224;</FONT></FONT> included on your proxy card or Notice of Internet Availability of Proxy Materials. Tickets will be available to
registered and beneficial owners and to one guest accompanying each registered and beneficial owner. <B>You must bring your ticket to the meeting to gain access. Requests for admission tickets will be processed in the order in which they are
received. Please note that seating is limited and requests for tickets will be accepted on a first-come, first-served basis.</B> </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B>*Enter the campus from Waukegan
Road at Overlook Drive. Signage will direct you to the meeting location. </B></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">Illinois Tool Works Inc. (&#147;ITW&#148; or the &#147;Company&#148;) is holding its
2016 Annual Meeting for the following purposes: </P> <P STYLE="font-size:4pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; font-family:ARIAL; font-size:10pt" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="7%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left">1.</TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top">To elect the eleven directors named in this proxy statement for the upcoming year; </TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:4pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>

<TD WIDTH="7%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left">4.</TD>

<TD WIDTH="7%">&nbsp;</TD>

of business on March&nbsp;8, 2016 are entitled to vote. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">Our annual report to stockholders for fiscal year 2015 is enclosed with this proxy statement. </P>

</TABLE></DIV>  <P STYLE="margin-top:3pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">March 23, 2016 </P>  <P STYLE="margin-top:12pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B>IMPORTANT NOTICE
REGARDING THE AVAILABILITY OF PROXY MATERIALS FOR THE ANNUAL MEETING OF STOCKHOLDERS TO BE HELD MAY 6, 2016: The Illinois Tool Works Inc. 2015 Annual Report to Stockholders, including the Annual Report on Form 10-K, and its 2016 Proxy Statement are
available on the Company&#146;s website at <U>www.itw.com</U> under the &#147;Investor Relations&#148; link. Paper copies are available without charge upon written request to the Company&#146;s address above, Attention: Secretary. </B></P>

<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

<div style="width:100%;margin-left:0%; margin-right:0%;border:solid 1.00pt;padding-top:2pt;padding-bottom:3pt">
<P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-top:12pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL" ALIGN="center"><B>Your Vote is Important </B></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:2%; margin-right:2%; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B>Whether or not you plan to attend the meeting, please vote as soon as possible. Under New York Stock Exchange rules, your broker will
NOT be able to vote your shares on Proposals 1, 3, 4, 5 or 6 unless they receive specific instructions from you.</B> If you hold your shares through a bank or brokerage account, we strongly encourage you to return the voting instruction card to your
bank, broker or other holder of record so that your vote is counted. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; margin-left:2%; margin-right:2%; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B>We encourage you to vote by internet or telephone.</B> It
is convenient for you and saves us significant postage and processing costs. Please see the section entitled &#147;How do I vote&#148; on page 1 for instructions on how to vote your shares. </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; padding-bottom:12pt; margin-left:2%; margin-right:2%; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B>We have been advised that some states are strictly enforcing unclaimed property laws and requiring shares held
in &#147;inactive&#148; accounts to be escheated to the state in which the stockholder was last known to reside. One way you can show that your account is active is to vote your shares. </B></P></div>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt ; font-size:8pt">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL" ALIGN="center">i </P>

<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:14pt; font-family:ARIAL" ALIGN="center"><FONT COLOR="#821928"><B><A NAME="rom41104_1"></A>Questions and Answers about the 2016 Annual Meeting and
Voting </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:ARIAL"><FONT COLOR="#821928"><B><I>What am I voting on and how does the Company&#146;s Board recommend that I vote? </I></B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">The Company&#146;s Board solicits your vote on the following proposals: </P> <P STYLE="font-size:12pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; font-family:ARIAL; font-size:10pt" ALIGN="center">


<TR>
<TD WIDTH="67%"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="24%"></TD>
<TD></TD></TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#821928" STYLE="font-family:ARIAL; font-size:11pt">
<TD VALIGN="middle" ALIGN="center" STYLE="BORDER-LEFT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-TOP:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000; padding-left:8pt"><FONT COLOR="#ffffff"><B><FONT COLOR="#ffffff">Proposal Submitted for
Vote</FONT></B></FONT></TD>

 COLOR="#ffffff"><B><FONT COLOR="#ffffff">Board<BR>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Recommendation&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="font-size:4pt; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:1pt" align="left">&nbsp;</P></TD></TR>


<TR STYLE="font-family:ARIAL; font-size:10pt">
<TD VALIGN="top" STYLE="BORDER-LEFT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000; padding-left:8pt"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.30em; text-indent:-1.30em; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">1.&nbsp;&nbsp;The election of the eleven directors named
in this proxy statement for the upcoming year</P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-LEFT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>

<TR STYLE="font-family:ARIAL; font-size:10pt">
<TD VALIGN="top" STYLE="BORDER-LEFT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000; padding-left:8pt"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.30em; text-indent:-1.30em; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">2.&nbsp;&nbsp;The ratification of the appointment of
Deloitte &amp; Touche LLP as our independent registered public accounting firm for 2016</P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-LEFT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>

<TD VALIGN="top" STYLE="BORDER-LEFT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000; padding-left:8pt"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.30em; text-indent:-1.30em; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">3.&nbsp;&nbsp;An advisory vote on executive
compensation</P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-LEFT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>

<TD VALIGN="top" STYLE="BORDER-LEFT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000; padding-left:8pt"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.30em; text-indent:-1.30em; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">4.&nbsp;&nbsp;Approval of an amendment to the Illinois
Tool Works Inc. Amended and Restated Certificate of Incorporation to permit stockholders to call special meetings</P></TD>

<TD VALIGN="top" STYLE="BORDER-LEFT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000; padding-left:8pt"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.30em; text-indent:-1.30em; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">5.&nbsp;&nbsp;Re-Approval of the material terms of the
performance goals under the Illinois Tool Works Inc. 2011 Cash Incentive Plan for purposes of Section 162(m) of the Internal Revenue Code</P></TD>

<TR STYLE="font-family:ARIAL; font-size:10pt">
<TD VALIGN="top" STYLE="BORDER-LEFT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000; padding-left:8pt">

Incentive Compensation Awards</P> <P STYLE="font-size:6pt; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:1pt">&nbsp;</P></TD>

<TD VALIGN="middle" STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000" ALIGN="center"> AGAINST<P STYLE="font-size:6pt; margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:1pt" align="left">&nbsp;</P></TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:ARIAL"><FONT COLOR="#821928"><B><I>Who may vote? </I></B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">Stockholders at the close of business on March&nbsp;8, 2016, the record date, may vote. On that date, there were 360,856,183 shares of ITW common stock outstanding. </P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:ARIAL"><FONT COLOR="#821928"><B><I>How many votes do I have? </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">Each share
of ITW common stock that you own entitles you to one vote. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:ARIAL"><FONT COLOR="#821928"><B><I>How do I vote? </I></B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">You may vote your shares in one of the following four ways: </P> <P STYLE="font-size:18pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; font-family:ARIAL; font-size:10pt" ALIGN="center">


<TR>
<TD WIDTH="21%"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="3%"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="76%"></TD></TR>


<TR STYLE="font-family:ARIAL; font-size:10pt">
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:2.70em; text-indent:-1.40em; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">1. By telephone:</P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">See the instructions at <U>www.proxyvote.com</U>;</TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="font-family:ARIAL; font-size:10pt">
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:2.70em; text-indent:-1.40em; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">2. By Internet:</P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">See the instructions at <U>www.proxyvote.com</U>;</TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="font-family:ARIAL; font-size:10pt">
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:2.70em; text-indent:-1.40em; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">3. By mail:</P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">If you received a printed copy of these proxy materials by mail, by</P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:1pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">signing, dating and mailing the enclosed proxy card; or</P></TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="font-family:ARIAL; font-size:10pt">
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:2.70em; text-indent:-1.40em; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">4. In person:</P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">Attend our Annual Meeting, where ballots will be provided.</TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">If you vote by telephone or Internet, you should have your proxy card or E-Proxy Notice in hand when you call or go to the proxy vote
site. If you hold your shares through a bank or broker that does not offer telephone or Internet voting, please complete and return your proxy card by mail. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:ARIAL"><FONT
 COLOR="#821928"><B><I>When must I submit my vote by Internet or by phone? </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">If you vote by Internet or by phone, you must transmit your vote by 10:59
p.m., Central Time, on May&nbsp;5, 2016. </P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt ; font-size:8pt">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL" ALIGN="center">1 </P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:ARIAL"><FONT COLOR="#821928"><B><I>If I hold shares through an ITW Savings and Investment 401(k) Plan, when must I submit my vote?
</I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">Shares held through an ITW 401(k) plan must be voted by 10:59 p.m., Central Time, on May&nbsp;3, 2016 in order to be tabulated in time for the
meeting. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:ARIAL"><FONT COLOR="#821928"><B><I>How does discretionary voting authority apply? </I></B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL"><I>Stockholders of Record.</I> If you are a stockholder of record and you vote by proxy, the individuals named on the proxy card (your proxies) will vote your shares in
the manner you indicate. If your proxy card does not indicate how you want to vote, your proxy will be voted as follows: </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">&#147;FOR&#148; the election of each
director nominee; </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">&#147;FOR&#148; the ratification of the appointment of Deloitte&nbsp;&amp; Touche LLP as our independent registered public accounting firm; </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">&#147;FOR&#148; the approval of ITW&#146;s executive compensation; </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">&#147;FOR&#148;
the approval of the amendment to our Amended and Restated Certificate of Incorporation to permit stockholders to call special meetings; </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">&#147;FOR&#148; the
re-approval of the material terms of the performance goals under the Illinois Tool Works Inc. 2011 Cash Incentive Plan for purposes of Section&nbsp;162(m) of the Internal Revenue Code; </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">&#147;AGAINST&#148; the non-binding stockholder proposal to exclude share repurchases from determinations of senior executive incentive compensation awards; and </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">&#147;FOR&#148; or &#147;AGAINST&#148; any other properly raised matter at the discretion of Susan Crown, Robert S. Morrison and Pamela B. Strobel, or any one of them.
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL"><I>Beneficial Owners.</I> If your shares are held in a brokerage account or by a nominee and you do not provide your broker or nominee with voting instructions, the
broker or nominee may represent your shares at the meeting for purposes of obtaining a quorum, but may not exercise discretion to vote your shares at the meeting unless the proposal is considered a routine matter. The only matter being proposed for
stockholder vote at the 2016 Annual Meeting that is considered a routine matter is the proposal to ratify the appointment of Deloitte&nbsp;&amp; Touche LLP as our independent registered public accounting firm. As a result, in the absence of voting
instructions from you, your broker or nominee will not have discretion to vote on any other matter to be voted on at the Annual Meeting. If you are a beneficial owner, it is important that you provide instructions to your bank, broker or other
holder of record so that your vote is counted. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:ARIAL"><FONT COLOR="#821928"><B><I>May I revoke my proxy? </I></B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">You may revoke your proxy at any time before it is voted at our Annual Meeting in one of four ways: </P>
<P STYLE="font-size:9pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; font-family:ARIAL; font-size:10pt" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="7%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left">1.</TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top">Notify our Secretary in writing before our Annual Meeting that you wish to revoke your proxy; </TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:9pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; font-family:ARIAL; font-size:10pt" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="7%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left">2.</TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top">Submit another proxy with a later date; </TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:9pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; font-family:ARIAL; font-size:10pt" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="7%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left">3.</TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top">Vote by telephone or Internet after you have given your proxy; or </TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:9pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; font-family:ARIAL; font-size:10pt" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="7%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left">4.</TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top">Vote in person at our Annual Meeting. </TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:ARIAL"><FONT COLOR="#821928"><B><I>Why didn&#146;t I receive a paper copy of the proxy
statement and annual report? </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">Unless our stockholders have requested paper copies, we are furnishing proxy materials through the Internet. If you
received a Notice of Internet Availability of Proxy Materials (E-Proxy Notice) by mail or electronically, you will not receive a printed copy of the proxy materials unless you specifically request </P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt ; font-size:8pt">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL" ALIGN="center">2 </P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">
one. Instead, the E-Proxy Notice provides instructions on how you may access and review our proxy materials online. The E-Proxy Notice also instructs you on how you may submit your proxy via the
Internet. If you received the E-Proxy Notice and would still like to receive a printed copy of our proxy materials without charge, you should follow the instructions for requesting such materials included in the E-Proxy Notice. </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:ARIAL"><FONT COLOR="#821928"><B><I>I have received paper copies&#151;how do I receive future proxy materials electronically? </I></B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">To sign up to receive stockholder communications electronically, follow the instructions on your proxy card or E-Proxy Notice under &#147;Vote by Internet.&#148; You
will need the 12-digit number that is printed in the box marked by the arrow <FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman"><FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:WINGDINGS">&#224;</FONT></FONT>, which appears on your proxy card or E-Proxy notice. This 12-digit number
is sometimes called the control number. In order to receive the communications electronically, you must have an e-mail account and access to the Internet. If you own your shares through a broker or other nominee, you may contact them directly to
request electronic access. Your consent to electronic access will be effective until you revoke it. You may revoke your consent by going to <U>www.proxyvote.com</U> and using the 12-digit number that is printed in the box marked by the arrow <FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman"><FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:WINGDINGS">&#224;</FONT></FONT> to complete the revocation. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:ARIAL"><FONT COLOR="#821928"><B><I>What does it
mean if I receive more than one E-Proxy Notice or set of proxy materials? </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">Your shares are likely registered differently or are in more than one
account. For each notice, proxy and/or voting instruction card or e-mail notification you receive that has a 12-digit number, you must vote separately to ensure that all shares you own are voted. </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:ARIAL"><FONT COLOR="#821928"><B><I>What constitutes a quorum? </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">The presence,
in person or by proxy, of the holders of a majority of ITW shares entitled to vote at our Annual Meeting constitutes a quorum. Your shares will be considered part of the quorum if you return a signed and dated proxy card or if you vote by telephone
or Internet. Abstentions and broker non-votes are counted as &#147;shares present&#148; at the meeting for purposes of determining if a quorum exists. A broker non-vote occurs when your bank, broker or other holder of record holding shares for you
as the beneficial owner submits a proxy that does not indicate a vote as to a non-routine proposal because that holder has not received voting instructions from you and, therefore, does not have voting authority for that proposal. </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:ARIAL"><FONT COLOR="#821928"><B><I>What vote is required to approve each proposal, assuming a quorum is present? </I></B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B><I>Election of Directors:&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></B>The number of shares voted &#147;FOR&#148; a director must exceed the number of shares voted &#147;AGAINST&#148; that
director to constitute approval by the stockholders. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B><I>Ratification of the Appointment of our Independent Registered Public Accounting
Firm:&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></B>The affirmative vote of a majority of the shares present in person or by proxy at the Annual Meeting and entitled to vote will constitute approval by the stockholders. </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B><I>Advisory (Non-Binding) Vote on ITW&#146;s Executive Compensation:&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></B>The affirmative vote of a majority of the shares present in person or by proxy
at the Annual Meeting and entitled to vote will constitute approval by the stockholders. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B><I>Approval of an Amendment to the Illinois Tool Works Inc. Amended and
Restated Certificate of Incorporation:&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></B>The affirmative vote of a majority of the shares outstanding and entitled to vote will constitute approval by the stockholders. </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B><I>Re-Approval of the Material Terms of the Performance Goals under the Illinois Tool Works Inc. 2011 Cash Incentive Plan for Purposes of Section&nbsp;162(m) of the
Internal Revenue Code.&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></B>The affirmative vote of a majority of the shares present in person or by proxy at the Annual Meeting and entitled to vote will constitute approval by the stockholders. </P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt ; font-size:8pt">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL" ALIGN="center">3 </P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL"><B><I>Approval of Non-Binding Stockholder Proposal to Exclude Share Repurchases from Determinations of Senior Executive
Incentive Compensation Awards.</I></B>&nbsp;&nbsp;The affirmative vote of a majority of the shares present in person or by proxy at the Annual Meeting and entitled to vote will constitute approval by the stockholders. </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:ARIAL"><FONT COLOR="#821928"><B><I>What is the effect of a broker non-vote generally and on each proposal? </I></B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">A broker non-vote occurs when a broker or other nominee does not receive voting instructions from the beneficial owner and does not have the discretion to direct the
voting of the shares. Broker non-votes will be counted for purposes of calculating whether a quorum is present at the Annual Meeting, but will not be counted for purposes of determining the number of votes present in person or represented by proxy
and entitled to vote with respect to a particular proposal. Broker non-votes will not, therefore, impact our ability to obtain a quorum and will have no effect on the election of directors, ratification of the appointment of our Independent
Registered Public Accounting Firm, approval of ITW&#146;s executive compensation, re-approval of performance goals or approval of the non-binding stockholder proposal. Broker non-votes will, however, have the same effect as a vote against the
amendment to our Amended and Restated Certificate of Incorporation, so we encourage our stockholders to vote &#147;FOR&#148; that proposal. </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:ARIAL"><FONT COLOR="#821928"><B><I>What if I &#147;abstain&#148; from voting? </I></B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">An abstention on the election of directors will have no effect on the outcome. An abstention on the other proposals will have the effect of a vote against those
proposals. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:ARIAL"><FONT COLOR="#821928"><B><I>How do I submit a stockholder proposal for the 2017 Annual Meeting? </I></B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">To be considered for inclusion in our proxy statement for our May 2017 Annual Meeting, a stockholder proposal must be received no later than November&nbsp;21, 2016. Your
proposal must be in writing and must comply with the proxy rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission, or SEC. You should send your proposal to our Secretary at our address on the Notice of Annual Meeting of Stockholders immediately following
the cover of this proxy statement. </P>  <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">You also may submit a proposal that you do not want included in the proxy statement, but that you want to raise at our May
2017 Annual Meeting. We must receive your proposal in writing on or after January&nbsp;6, 2017, but no later than February&nbsp;5, 2017. As detailed in the advance notice procedures described in our by-laws, for a proposal other than the nomination
of a director to be properly brought before an annual meeting, your notice of proposal must include: (1)&nbsp;your name and address, as well as the name and address of the beneficial owner of the shares, if any; (2)&nbsp;the number of shares of ITW
stock owned beneficially and of record by you and any beneficial owner as of the date of the notice (which information must be supplemented as of the record date); (3)&nbsp;a description of certain agreements, arrangements or understandings entered
into by you or any beneficial owner with respect to the shares (which information must be supplemented as of the record date) or the business proposed to be brought before the meeting; (4)&nbsp;any other information regarding you or any beneficial
owner that would be required under the SEC&#146;s proxy rules and regulations; and (5)&nbsp;a brief description of the business you propose to be brought before the meeting, the reasons for conducting that business at the meeting, and any material
interest that you or any beneficial owner has in that business. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:ARIAL"><FONT COLOR="#821928"><B><I>Does ITW allow stockholders to have proxy access for the nomination of
directors? </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">Yes. In 2015, we reached out to holders of approximately 50% of our shares to engage on matters of corporate governance, including the
right of proxy access. The majority of those with whom we spoke were in favor of granting this right, and several stockholders expressed a preference for reasonable limitations on proxy access. The board of directors discussed proxy access over the
course of several </P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt ; font-size:8pt">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL" ALIGN="center">4 </P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">
meetings, and on December&nbsp;11, 2015, the board adopted proxy access bylaw provisions to permit stockholders to include nominees in the Company&#146;s proxy statement and form of proxy. See
&#147;Corporate Governance Policies and Practices &#150; Shareholder Engagement&#148; for a description of our shareholder engagement activities. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:ARIAL"><FONT
 COLOR="#821928"><B><I>How do I use proxy access to nominate a director candidate to be included in ITW&#146;s 2017 Proxy Statement? </I></B></FONT></P>  <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">Any
stockholder or group of up to 20 stockholders meeting our continuous ownership requirement of 3% or more of our common stock for at least 3 years who wishes to nominate a candidate or candidates for election in connection with our 2017 Annual
Meeting and require us to include such nominees in our proxy statement and form of proxy, must submit such nomination and request so that it is received by our Secretary on or after January&nbsp;6, 2017, but no later than February&nbsp;5, 2017. The
number of candidates that may be so nominated is limited to the greater of two or the largest whole number that does not exceed 25% of the Board. Recallable loaned shares count as owned for purposes of meeting the continuous ownership requirement,
but each stockholder in the requesting group must have full voting and investment rights as well as economic interest in their shares at the time of nomination, record date and meeting date. Two or more investment funds that are part of the same
family of funds or sponsored by the same employer will count as one stockholder for purposes of determining the size of the group. All proxy access nominations must be accompanied by information about the nominating stockholders as well as the
nominees and meet the requirements as specified in Article II, Section&nbsp;12 of our bylaws, which include but are not limited to, the information specified under &#147;How do I nominate a director candidate who would not be included in ITW&#146;s
Proxy Statement?&#148; below. </P>  <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:ARIAL"><FONT COLOR="#821928"><B><I>How do I nominate a director candidate who would not be included in ITW&#146;s Proxy Statement?
</I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">If you wish to nominate an individual for election as a director at our May 2017 Annual Meeting, our Secretary must receive your written nomination
on or after January&nbsp;6, 2017, but no later than February&nbsp;5, 2017. As detailed in the advance notice procedures described in our by-laws, for a nomination to be properly brought before an annual meeting, your notice of nomination must
include: (1)&nbsp;your name and address, as well as the name and address of the beneficial owner of the shares, if any; (2)&nbsp;the number of shares of ITW stock owned beneficially and of record by you and any beneficial owner as of the date of the
notice (which information must be supplemented as of the record date); (3)&nbsp;a description of certain agreements, arrangements or understandings entered into by you or any beneficial owner with respect to the shares (which information must be
supplemented as of the record date); (4)&nbsp;the name, age and home and business addresses of the nominee; (5)&nbsp;the principal occupation or employment of the nominee; (6)&nbsp;the number of shares of ITW stock that the nominee beneficially
owns; (7)&nbsp;a statement that the nominee is willing to be nominated and serve as a director; (8)&nbsp;a statement as to whether the nominee, if elected, intends to tender his or her resignation in accordance with our Corporate Governance
Guidelines; (9)&nbsp;an undertaking to provide any other information required to determine the eligibility of the nominee to serve as an independent director or that could be material to stockholders&#146; understanding of the nominee&#146;s
independence; and (10)&nbsp;any other information regarding you, any beneficial owner or the nominee that would be required under the SEC&#146;s proxy rules and regulations had our Board of Directors nominated the individual. Any nomination that you
make must be approved by our Corporate Governance and Nominating Committee, as well as by our Board of Directors. The process for the selection of director candidates is described under &#147;Corporate Governance Policies and Practices &#151;
Director Candidate Selection Process&#148; below. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:ARIAL"><FONT COLOR="#821928"><B><I>Who pays to prepare, mail and solicit the proxies? </I></B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">We will pay the cost of solicitation of proxies including preparing, printing and mailing this proxy statement and the E-Proxy Notice. We will also authorize brokers,
dealers, banks, voting trustees and </P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt ; font-size:8pt">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL" ALIGN="center">5 </P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">
other nominees and fiduciaries to forward copies of the proxy materials to the beneficial owners of ITW common stock. Upon request, we will reimburse them for their reasonable expenses. In
addition, our officers, directors and employees may solicit proxies in person, by mail, by telephone or otherwise. In the event that we decide to engage a proxy solicitation firm to assist with the solicitation of proxies, we would expect to engage
Georgeson, and we estimate that the additional cost to be borne by us would be approximately $12,000 plus reasonable and approved out-of-pocket expenses. </P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt ; font-size:8pt">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL" ALIGN="center">6 </P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:14pt; font-family:ARIAL" ALIGN="center"><FONT COLOR="#821928"><B><A NAME="rom41104_2"></A>Proposal 1 - Election of Directors </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">Stockholders are being asked to elect the eleven directors named in this proxy statement at our Annual Meeting. The individuals listed below have been nominated by the
Board of Directors as recommended by the Corporate Governance and Nominating Committee. See &#147;Corporate Governance Policies and Practices&#148; for more information regarding our candidate selection process. Each director will serve until the
May 2017 Annual Meeting, until a qualified successor director has been elected, or until he or she resigns or is removed. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">We will vote your shares as you specify on
the proxy card, by telephone, by Internet or by mail. If you do not specify how you want your shares voted, we will vote them &#147;FOR&#148; the election of all the nominees listed below. If unforeseen circumstances (such as death or disability)
make it necessary for the Board of Directors to substitute another person for any of the nominees, we will vote your shares &#147;FOR&#148; that other person. The Board of Directors does not anticipate that any nominee will be unable to serve. </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">Each nominee for director brings a strong and unique background and set of skills to the Board, giving the Board as a whole competence and experience in a variety of
areas. Set forth below is biographical information provided by the nominees, as well as a description of the experiences, qualifications, skills and attributes that led the Corporate Governance and Nominating Committee and the Board to conclude that
each nominee should serve as a director of the Company. </P> <P STYLE="font-size:9pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; font-family:ARIAL; font-size:10pt" ALIGN="center">

<TD VALIGN="bottom"> <P STYLE="font-size:12pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL"><FONT STYLE="font-size:11pt"><B><I>Daniel J. Brutto,</I></B></FONT> 59,
retired as President of UPS International and Senior Vice President of United Parcel Service, Inc., a global package delivery, supply chain management and freight forwarding company, having served in these capacities from January 2008 to June 2013.
Previously, he served as President, Global Freight Forwarding, for UPS from 2006 to 2007, and corporate controller from 2004 to 2006. Mr. Brutto had over 38 years of experience at UPS, serving over the years in various areas with increasing levels
of responsibility, including operations, finance, information systems, mergers &amp; acquisitions, marketing, business development and international. Mr. Brutto is currently Vice Chairman of eBay Enterprise/Innotrac Corporation, a privately held
global fulfillment, customer care and technology company, and has served as a director of ITW since 2012. In the past, Mr. Brutto served on the board of the US-China Business Council, the Guangdong Economic Council, and the Turkey Economic Advisory
Council. He was also a delegate to the World Economic Forum, Davos, Switzerland, from 2009 to 2013. He has not served as a director of any other publicly-traded company in the last five years.</P>
<P STYLE="font-size:9pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:1pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">Mr. Brutto&#146;s significant strategic, operational, and financial leadership experience with a
major global company, including the establishment of operations in 35 countries, along with his significant international business experience, brings valuable perspectives to our
Board.</P></TD></TR></TABLE>

and Timken&#146;s bearing business activities in Asia and Latin America. Prior to joining Timken, he held production and engineering positions at Martin Marietta, Bunker Hill Company and Homestake Mining Company. Mr. Griffith is currently a director

Exelon Corporation and President of Exelon Business Services Company, an electric and gas utility company, in October 2005, a position she had held since 2003, previously serving as Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Exelon Energy Delivery from
2000 to 2003. Prior thereto, she served as Executive Vice President of Unicom and its chief subsidiary, ComEd, having joined ComEd as General Counsel in 1993. Ms. Strobel is currently a director of Domtar Corporation and State Farm Mutual Automobile
Insurance Company and has not served as a director of any other publicly-traded company in the last five years. Ms. Strobel has served as a director of ITW since 2008.</P> <P STYLE="font-size:9pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>

<TR STYLE="font-size:1pt">
<TD HEIGHT="16"></TD>
<TD HEIGHT="16" COLSPAN="2"></TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="font-family:ARIAL; font-size:10pt">
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em">


<IMG SRC="g41104g81d72.jpg" ALT="LOGO">
</P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL"><FONT STYLE="font-size:11pt"><B><I>Kevin M. Warren,</I></B></FONT> 53, has been the President, Commercial Business Group for Xerox Corporation, a
global business services, technology and document management company, since January 2016 and previously served as the President, Industrial, Retail and Hospitality Business Group since January 2015. Since 1984, Mr. Warren has held a number of
positions at Xerox with increasing levels of responsibility, including as President of Strategic Growth Initiatives for Xerox Corporation from January 2014 to January 2015; President of U.S. Client Operations for Xerox Corporation from June 2010 to
December 2013; Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer of Xerox Canada from 2007 to 2010; Senior Vice President, Acquisition Transition Office in 2007; and Senior Vice President, U.S. Eastern Sales, U.S. Solutions Group from 2004 to 2007. He
also serves as a director of a number of professional, civic and not-for-profit organizations. Mr. Warren has served as a director of ITW since 2010 and has not served as a director of any other publicly-traded company in the last five years.</P>
<P STYLE="font-size:9pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:1pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">Mr. Warren&#146;s significant strategic and operational leadership experience with a major global
company, along with his significant international experience, brings valuable perspectives to our Board.</P></TD></TR></TABLE>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt ; font-size:8pt">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL" ALIGN="center">10 </P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>

<TR STYLE="font-family:ARIAL; font-size:10pt">
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em">


<IMG SRC="g41104g64j68.jpg" ALT="LOGO">
</P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL"><FONT STYLE="font-size:11pt"><B><I>Anr&eacute; D. Williams</I></B></FONT><B>,</B> 50, has been President, Global Merchant Service &amp; Loyalty
Group, of American Express Company, a global services company, since October 2015. From 2011 to 2015, Mr. Williams was President, Global Merchant Services. From 2007 to 2011, Mr. Williams was President, Global Commercial Card, of American Express.
From 1989 to 2007, Mr. Williams held several positions at American Express, serving as Executive Vice President, U.S. Commercial Card, from 2003 to 2007; Senior Vice President, U.S. Middle Market, from 2000 to 2003; Vice President and General
Manager, Western Region, Corporate Services, from 1999 to 2000; and Vice President, Acquisition and Advertising, from 1996 to 1999. Mr. Williams has served as a director of ITW since 2010 and is a former director of Ryerson Inc. Mr. Williams has not
served as a director of any other publicly-traded company in the last five years.</P> <P STYLE="font-size:9pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:1pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">Mr.
Williams&#146; significant strategic and operational leadership experience with a major global financial services company, along with his global business experience, bring valuable perspectives to our Board.</P></TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:24pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:ARIAL" ALIGN="center"><B>The Board of Directors recommends a vote &#147;FOR&#148; the election of all of the above nominees. </B></P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt ; font-size:8pt">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL" ALIGN="center">11 </P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:12pt; font-family:ARIAL"><FONT COLOR="#821928"><B><A NAME="rom41104_3"></A>Board of Directors and Its Committees </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="line-height:4.0pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:2pt;border-bottom:2.00pt solid #821928">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">The Company&#146;s Board of Directors met five times during
2015. In addition to these Board meetings, directors attended meetings of Board committees. Non-employee directors, all of whom are independent, met five times in regularly scheduled executive sessions in conjunction with regular Board meetings.
Robert S. Morrison serves as Lead Director of the Board. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:ARIAL"><FONT COLOR="#821928"><B><I>Role of Chairman and CEO </I></B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">Pursuant to the Company&#146;s Corporate Governance Guidelines, the Board examines whether the role of chairman and chief executive officer should be combined each time
the Board elects a new CEO, and may determine to separate or combine the offices of chairman and CEO at such other times as it deems appropriate. E. Scott Santi was elected President and CEO in November 2012, and the Board decided to separate the
roles of CEO and Chairman at that time. Given Mr.&nbsp;Santi&#146;s successful transition into the CEO role and his deep knowledge and understanding of the Company&#146;s business model, operations and culture, the Board determined that he is best
positioned to lead the Board in its ongoing oversight of the Company&#146;s operations and strategy. In May 2015, the Board elected Mr.&nbsp;Santi Chairman of the Board and CEO, and elected Robert S. Morrison, who was then non-executive Chairman, as
lead director. The Board believes that this structure, which includes a strong, independent and highly experienced lead director with well-defined responsibilities, along with the Company&#146;s experienced and engaged independent directors,
provides effective oversight of the Company&#146;s management. The Board simultaneously amended the Company&#146;s Corporate Governance Guidelines to enhance the duties of the lead director. As amended, the Corporate Governance Guidelines state that
the lead director will: </P> <P STYLE="font-size:9pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; font-family:ARIAL; font-size:10pt" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="9%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left">&#149;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top">preside at all meetings of the Board at which the chairman is not present, including executive sessions of the independent directors; </TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="font-size:9pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; font-family:ARIAL; font-size:10pt" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="9%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left">&#149;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top">act as a key liaison between the chairman and the independent directors; </TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:9pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; font-family:ARIAL; font-size:10pt" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="9%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left">&#149;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top">have the authority to call meetings of the independent directors, when necessary; </TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:9pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; font-family:ARIAL; font-size:10pt" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="9%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left">&#149;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top">approve meeting agendas, schedules and information sent to the Board; </TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:9pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; font-family:ARIAL; font-size:10pt" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="9%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left">&#149;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top">communicate Board member feedback to the chairman after each Board meeting; </TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:9pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; font-family:ARIAL; font-size:10pt" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="9%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left">&#149;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top">if requested by major stockholders, ensure that he or she is available for consultation and direct communication; and </TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:9pt;margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; font-family:ARIAL; font-size:10pt" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="9%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left">&#149;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top">perform such other duties as requested by the Board. </TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">The Board of Directors has standing audit, compensation, corporate
governance and nominating, finance, and executive committees. Under the terms of their respective charters, each member of the audit, compensation, and corporate governance and nominating committees must meet applicable New York Stock Exchange
(&#147;NYSE&#148;) and SEC independence requirements. The Company strongly encourages its directors to attend all Board and committee meetings and the Annual Meeting of Stockholders. In 2015, all of the directors attended at least 75% of the
meetings of the Board and the committees on which they serve. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:ARIAL"><FONT COLOR="#821928"><B><I>Audit Committee </I></B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">The Audit Committee is responsible for the integrity of the Company&#146;s financial statements, compliance with legal and regulatory requirements, the independence and
performance of ITW&#146;s independent registered public accounting firm, and the performance of the Company&#146;s internal audit function. In addition, the Committee is responsible for the engagement of our independent registered public accounting
firm and assists the Board with respect to matters involving and overseeing accounting, </P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt ; font-size:8pt">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL" ALIGN="center">12 </P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">
financial reporting and internal audit functions. Finally, the Audit Committee, on behalf of the Board of Directors, reviews and evaluates certain of our policies and practices with respect to
risk assessment and risk management and steps taken by management to monitor and control such exposures. Additional information on the Committee and its activities is set forth under &#147;Audit Committee Report&#148; below. </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:ARIAL"><FONT COLOR="#821928"><B><I>Compensation Committee </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">The Compensation
Committee establishes and oversees the Company&#146;s executive compensation philosophy, programs and policies, including ensuring that executive compensation is aligned to Company and individual performance. The Compensation Committee recommends to
the other independent directors compensation for the chief executive officer, reviews and approves the chief executive officer&#146;s recommendations regarding the compensation of our other executive officers, and makes recommendations regarding new
incentive compensation and equity-based plans or amendments to any existing plans. The Compensation Committee also is responsible for reviewing and evaluating risks arising from our compensation policies and practices and providing input to
management on whether such policies and practices may have a material adverse effect on the Company. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">Under its charter, the Compensation Committee may retain an
independent compensation consultant or other advisors. The Compensation Committee engaged Frederic W. Cook&nbsp;&amp; Co., Inc., an independent consultant, as its independent advisor to review the Company&#146;s overall executive compensation
program, review the peer group of companies used by the Compensation Committee for comparison purposes and assess our compensation governance process. Based on representations from Cook and executive officers and directors of the Company, the
Compensation Committee has determined that Cook and its individual compensation advisor to the committee are independent. See &#147;Compensation Discussion and Analysis &#151; How We Make Compensation Decisions &#151; Role of the Compensation
Consultant.&#148; </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">Additional information on the Compensation Committee, its activities, its relationship with its compensation consultant and the role of management
in setting compensation is provided under &#147;Compensation Discussion and Analysis&#148; below. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:ARIAL"><FONT COLOR="#821928"><B><I>Corporate Governance and Nominating
Committee </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">The Corporate Governance and Nominating Committee identifies, evaluates and recommends director candidates; develops, administers and
recommends corporate governance guidelines; oversees the evaluations of the performance and procedures of the Board and individual directors; makes recommendations as to Board committees and Board size and makes a recommendation to the Board
regarding the Board&#146;s determination of director independence for the Board, the Audit Committee and the Compensation Committee. This committee also oversees and makes recommendations to the independent directors regarding non-employee director
compensation. See &#147;Corporate Governance Policies and Practices &#151; Director Candidate Selection Process&#148; below for a description of the director selection process. </P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:ARIAL"><FONT COLOR="#821928"><B><I>Finance Committee </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">The Finance Committee
reviews, evaluates and recommends management&#146;s proposals to the Board relating to the Company&#146;s financings and investments, and reviews and evaluates an annual summary of the funding and investment status of significant benefit plans
sponsored by the Company globally. The Finance Committee also periodically reviews and evaluates the Company&#146;s capital allocation strategy as well as risks arising from the Company&#146;s investments, treasury function (such as derivatives and
interest rates) and liquidity. </P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0pt;margin-bottom:0pt ; font-size:8pt">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL" ALIGN="center">13 </P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:ARIAL"><FONT COLOR="#821928"><B><I>Executive Committee </I></B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">The Executive Committee may act on behalf of the Board if a matter requires Board action between meetings of the full Board. The Executive Committee&#146;s authority in
certain matters is limited by law and our by-laws. </P> <P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:11pt; font-family:ARIAL"><FONT COLOR="#821928"><B><I>Committee Memberships </I></B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:9pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:ARIAL">The following table shows the current committee memberships and the number of meetings held by each committee during 2015. </P>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-LEFT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="center" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000">4</TD>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="center" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000">3</TD>
